page.title: 16Scotch Corner Hotel
page.content: Scotch Corner takes its name from an old Roman road called Scotts Dyke. The Scottish border farmers used to bring their sheep here to market and it was the most southerly place that these farmers travelled to. It was and still is an important road junction for transport with the main trunk roads linking Scotland with England and East Coast with West Coast. The{SCOTCH CORNER HOTEL}occupies a prominent and elevated site, the original building dated from the mid- 16th Century whilst the present hotel was built and opened in June 1939. It has undergone internal refurbishment since then. It was previously named the Three Tuns Inn and was a coaching inn where teams of horses were changed on long journeys and travellers rested and dined. There is a picture in the hotel showing it as it was in 1890.
